entry.title: Python setup.py, How to install package by your self

link.title: Python setup.py, How to install package by your self

entry.content:
Code

  • Home Page - Github
  • Pypi Page
  • setup.py file
from setuptools import setup, find_packages

with open('requirements.txt', mode="r", encoding="utf8") as f:
    required = f.read().splitlines()

setup(
    name='cuefig',
    version='0.0.2',
    url='https://github.com/FavorMylikes/cuefig',
    license='MIT License',
    author='È∫¶‰∏ΩÁ¥†',
    author_email='l786112323@gmail.com',
    description='A config framework that you can cue and hint quickly.',
    package_data={"": ["*.yaml"], },
    classifiers=[
        "Programming Language :: Python :: 3",
        "License :: OSI Approved :: MIT License",
        "Operating System :: OS Independent",
    ],
    install_requires=required,
    packages=find_packages(),
    python_requires=">=3.7",
)
  • tree
‚îÇ   LICENSE
‚îÇ   main.py
‚îÇ   README.md
‚îÇ   requirements.txt
‚îÇ   setup.py
‚îÇ
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄcuefig
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   __init__.py
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄlogger
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ       logging.yaml
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ       __init__.py
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄutils
‚îÇ           __init__.py
  • install
python ./setup.py install
  • deploy
python setup.py check
python -m build
python -m twine upload --skip-existing --repository pypi dist/* --verbose

Hint

  • You can not upload save version dist twice
  • Use ~/.pypirc to save pypi token

Reference

  • Ëä±‰∫Ü‰∏§Â§©ÔºåÁªà‰∫éÊää Python ÁöÑ setup.py ÁªôÊï¥ÊòéÁôΩ‰∫Ü - ÁéãÁÇ≥ÊòéÁöÑÊñáÁ´† - Áü•‰πé
  • Âà∂‰ΩúÂü∫‰∫épbrÁöÑpythonÂèØÂèëÂ∏Épackage - CSDN
  • pytorchÈÄöËøátorch.utils.cpp_extensionÊûÑÂª∫CUDA/C++ÊãìÂ±ï - CSDN
  • Packageing project - pythonü§ô

entry.title: Python speed up, Campare for numba and cuda

link.title: Python speed up, Campare for numba and cuda

entry.content:
numba

Code

from timeit import timeit

import numpy as np
import numba
from numba import jit, njit


# ‰º†ÂÖ•jitÔºånumbaË£ÖÈ•∞Âô®‰∏≠ÁöÑ‰∏ÄÁßç
@jit(nopython=True)
def go_fast(a):  # È¶ñÊ¨°Ë∞ÉÁî®Êó∂ÔºåÂáΩÊï∞Ë¢´ÁºñËØë‰∏∫Êú∫Âô®‰ª£Á†Å
    trace = 0
    # ÂÅáËÆæËæìÂÖ•ÂèòÈáèÊòØnumpyÊï∞ÁªÑ
    for i in range(a.shape[0]):  # Numba ÊìÖÈïøÂ§ÑÁêÜÂæ™ÁéØ
        trace += np.tanh(a[i, i])  # numbaÂñúÊ¨¢numpyÂáΩÊï∞
    return a + trace  # numbaÂñúÊ¨¢numpyÂπøÊí≠


@jit(nopython=True)
def go(a):
    t = np.zeros(a.shape[0])
    for i in range(a.shape[0]):
        t[i] = a[i, i]
    return a + np.sum(np.tanh(t))


x = np.arange(100).astype(np.float64).reshape(10, 10)

Blog

  • How do Cython, Numba, and PyPy compare in terms of performance, ease of use, and restrictions - Quora
  • ‰ºòÂåñ Python ÊÄßËÉΩÔºöPyPy„ÄÅNumba ‰∏é CythonÔºåË∞ÅÊâçÊòØÁõÆÂâçÊúÄ‰ºòÁßÄÁöÑ Python ËøêÁÆóËß£ÂÜ≥ÊñπÊ°àÔºü - ÁöÆÁöÆÂÖ≥ÁöÑÂõûÁ≠î - Áü•‰πé
  • numbaÔºåËÆ©pythonÈÄüÂ∫¶ÊèêÂçáÁôæÂÄç - Êú±Âç´ÂÜõÁöÑÊñáÁ´† - Áü•‰πé

Result

method jit timeit
go_fast ¬† 11.3 ¬µs ¬± 147 ns per loop (mean ¬± std. dev. of 7 runs, 100000 loops each)
go_fast njit 805 ns ¬± 9.31 ns per loop (mean ¬± std. dev. of 7 runs, 1000000 loops each)
go ¬† 7.43 ¬µs ¬± 45.6 ns per loop (mean ¬± std. dev. of 7 runs, 100000 loops each)
go njit 921 ns ¬± 9.16 ns per loop (mean ¬± std. dev. of 7 runs, 1000000 loops each)

cuda

Code Cuda

  • compile
nvcc -std=c++11 -o nbody nbody.cu
  • report
nsys profile --stats=true --force-overwrite=true -o nbody-report ./nbody

entry.title: Rotation Training by backward progation
entry.content:
Fix light parameter

With Sobel Loss

RANDOM_UV = False
UV_SHAPE = 1024, 1024, 3
UV_TRAIN = False
AMBIENT_TRAIN: bool = True
DIFFUSE_TRAIN: bool = False
SPECULAR_TRAIN: bool = False
LOCATION_TRAIN: bool = False

expect_value 
euler_angles_to_matrix(rotation_mask.rotation[i] / 10, 'XYZ') @
euler_angles_to_matrix(torch.tensor([-.1, -.2, -.03], device=device), 'ZYX')

With Pixel Loss

RANDOM_UV = False
UV_SHAPE = 1024, 1024, 3
UV_TRAIN = False
AMBIENT_TRAIN: bool = True
DIFFUSE_TRAIN: bool = False
SPECULAR_TRAIN: bool = False
LOCATION_TRAIN: bool = False

expect_value 
euler_angles_to_matrix(rotation_mask.rotation[i] / 10, 'XYZ') @
euler_angles_to_matrix(torch.tensor([-.1, -.2, -.03], device=device), 'ZYX')

entry.title: Pytorch Distributed Training Dataloader Test
entry.content:
How the dataloader split data into mutly devices

Code

from typing import List

import torch
from torch.distributed import init_process_group, get_rank
from torch.utils.data import Dataset, DataLoader, DistributedSampler
from tqdm import tqdm


class TestDataset(Dataset):
    def __init__(self, size: int):
        self.size = size
        self.data: List[int] = list(range(size))

    def __len__(self):
        return self.size

    def __getitem__(self, index):
        return self.data[index]


init_process_group(backend="nccl")
rank = get_rank()
torch.cuda.set_device(rank)
device = torch.device("cuda", rank)

BATCH_SIZE = 1

dataset = TestDataset(3)
loader = DataLoader(dataset, batch_size=BATCH_SIZE, num_workers=0, drop_last=True,
                    sampler=DistributedSampler(dataset, shuffle=True)
                    )
bar = tqdm(enumerate(loader, 0), leave=True, total=len(loader), position=0, disable=True)
for i, data in bar:
    print((rank, i, data.cuda()))

Command

PYTHONUNBUFFERED=1;CUDA_VISIBLE_DEVICES=0,7;OMP_NUM_THREADS=1;CUDA_LAUNCH_BLOCKING=0
-u -m torch.distributed.run --nproc_per_node=2

Result

  • size = 1

    • (rank:0, i:0, tensor([0], device='cuda:0'))
(rank:1, i:0, tensor([0], device='cuda:1'))

  • size = 2

    • (rank:0, i:0, tensor([0], device='cuda:0'))
(rank:1, i:0, tensor([1], device='cuda:1'))

  • size = 3

    • means pytorch will pick enough data to fill a batch

    • (rank:0, i:0, tensor([2], device='cuda:0'))
(rank:0, i:1, tensor([1], device='cuda:0'))
(rank:1, i:0, tensor([0], device='cuda:1'))
(rank:1, i:1, tensor([2], device='cuda:1'))

Comment

  • here the data model will not synchronism

DDP

import random
from typing import List

import torch
import numpy as np
from torch import distributed, optim, nn, Tensor
from torch.distributed import init_process_group, get_rank
from torch.nn.parallel import DistributedDataParallel
from torch.utils.data import Dataset, DataLoader, DistributedSampler
from tqdm import tqdm


def setup_seed(seed):
    torch.manual_seed(seed)
    torch.cuda.manual_seed_all(seed)
    np.random.seed(seed)
    random.seed(seed)
    torch.use_deterministic_algorithms(True)


def reduce_tensor(tensor: torch.Tensor) -> torch.Tensor:
    rt = tensor.clone()
    distributed.all_reduce(rt, op=distributed.ReduceOp.SUM)
    rt /= distributed.get_world_size()
    return rt


class TestModule(nn.Module):
    def __init__(self, x: Tensor):
        super().__init__()
        self.x = nn.Parameter(x)

    def forward(self, u: Tensor):
        return torch.norm(u - self.x, 2)


class TestDataset(Dataset):
    def __init__(self, size: int):
        self.size = size
        self.data: List[int] = list(range(size))

    def __len__(self):
        return self.size

    def __getitem__(self, index):
        return self.data[index]


init_process_group(backend="nccl")
rank = get_rank()
torch.cuda.set_device(rank)
device = torch.device("cuda", rank)

BATCH_SIZE = 1
SEED = 42
setup_seed(SEED)
dataset = TestDataset(2)
loader = DataLoader(dataset, batch_size=BATCH_SIZE, num_workers=2, drop_last=True,
                    sampler=DistributedSampler(dataset, shuffle=True)
                    )
bar = tqdm(enumerate(loader, 0), leave=True, total=len(loader), position=0, disable=True)

total = torch.tensor(0.).cuda()
x = torch.Tensor([0.]).cuda()
model = TestModule(x)
model = DistributedDataParallel(model)
optimizer = optim.Adam(model.parameters(), lr=.1)
for i, data in bar:
    num = data.cuda()
    if rank == 0:
        # will lead the tensor reduce hangs
        continue
    loss = model(num)
    optimizer.zero_grad()
    loss.backward()
    optimizer.step()
    total += loss.sum()

total_reduce = reduce_tensor(total)
print(x)
print(total_reduce)

PYTHONUNBUFFERED=1;CUDA_VISIBLE_DEVICES=0,7;OMP_NUM_THREADS=1;CUDA_LAUNCH_BLOCKING=0
-u -m torch.distributed.run --nproc_per_node=2

About reduce api

all_reduce(x, op=ReduceOp.SUM, async_op=True)
# Here async_op Ë°®Á§∫ÂêåÊ≠•ËøòÊòØÂºÇÊ≠•Ôºådefault as False
# Â¶ÇÊûúÊòØÂºÇÊ≠•ÔºåÂàô‰∏çÂêåÁöÑËøõÁ®ãÂæóÂà∞ÁöÑÁªìÊûúÊòØ‰∏çÂêåÁöÑ

init_process_group(backend="nccl")
rank = get_rank()
torch.cuda.set_device(rank)
device = torch.device("cuda", rank)
item_inner = torch.tensor(1.).cuda()
item_outer = torch.tensor(1.).cuda()
# print((rank, x))
if rank == 0:
    time.sleep(10)
op_outer = all_reduce(item_outer, async_op=True)
# ÈöêÂºèÂèòÈáè‰æùÁÑ∂ÂèØ‰ª•‰øùÊåÅÂêåÊ≠•
op_inner = all_reduce(item_inner, op=ReduceOp.SUM, async_op=True)
op_inner.wait()
# Â¶ÇÊûúop_innerÂ∑≤ÂÆåÊàêÁ≠âÂæÖÔºåÂàôop_outer‰πüÂ∑≤ÂÆåÊàêreduceËÆ°ÁÆó
# Âèç‰πãop_outerÂ∑≤ÂÆåÊàêÁ≠âÂæÖÔºåop_innerÊú™ÂøÖÂÆåÊàêËÆ°ÁÆó
print((rank, item_inner.item()))
print((rank, item_outer.item()))

Reference

  • [ÂéüÂàõ][Ê∑±Â∫¶][PyTorch] DDPÁ≥ªÂàóÁ¨¨‰∏ÄÁØáÔºöÂÖ•Èó®ÊïôÁ®ã - 996ÈªÑÈáë‰∏Ä‰ª£ÁöÑÊñáÁ´† - Áü•‰πé
  • [ÂéüÂàõ][Ê∑±Â∫¶][PyTorch] DDPÁ≥ªÂàóÁ¨¨‰∫åÁØáÔºöÂÆûÁé∞ÂéüÁêÜ‰∏éÊ∫ê‰ª£Á†ÅËß£Êûê - 996ÈªÑÈáë‰∏Ä‰ª£ÁöÑÊñáÁ´† - Áü•‰πé
  • [ÂéüÂàõ][Ê∑±Â∫¶][PyTorch] DDPÁ≥ªÂàóÁ¨¨‰∏âÁØáÔºöÂÆûÊàò‰∏éÊäÄÂ∑ß - 996ÈªÑÈáë‰∏Ä‰ª£ÁöÑÊñáÁ´† - Áü•‰πé
  • Zhiyuan Chen - zyc.ai
  • Best practice for uneven dataset sizes with DistributedDataParallel - discuss.pytorch.org
  • Support uneven DDP inputs - github.com
  • Hook
    • How to Use PyTorch Hooks - Frank Odom - medium

entry.title: The Coordinate System - How to convert between different coordinate system

link.title: The Coordinate System - How to convert between different coordinate system

entry.content:
Coordinate System

system image System hand Rotation hand Camera Order
OpenGL RH RH (0,0,-1) XYZ
Unity LH LH (0,0,1) YXZ(local) zxy(global)
pytorch3d RH LH (0,0,1) XYZ
OpenCV RH RH (0,0,1) XYZ
scipy ¬† RH LH ¬† XYZ xyz

Docs

  • scipy
    • quat = [x,y,z,w]
    • euler
      • XYZ means intrinsic rotations ÂÜÖÂú®ÊóãËΩ¨,Conventions by intrinsic rotations
        • intrinsic rotations ÊåáÊØèÊ¨°ÊóãËΩ¨ÁöÑÊóãËΩ¨ËΩ¥ÈÉΩÊòØ‰∏äÊ¨°ÂèòÊç¢ÂêéÊñ∞ÂùêÊ†áÁ≥ª
      • xyz means extrinsic rotations Â§ñÂú®ÊóãËΩ¨,Conventions by extrinsic rotations
        • extrinsic rotations ÊåáÊØèÊ¨°ÊóãËΩ¨ÁöÑÊóãËΩ¨ËΩ¥ÈÉΩÊòØÂõ∫ÂÆöÁöÑÂèÇËÄÉÁ≥ª
  • unity
    • rotation
      • local rotation: intrinsic rotations, YXZ
      • global rotation: extrinsic rotations, zxy
    • order: YXZ
  • math
    • Rodrigues: $r_{vert} = [x,y,z]$, $ r_{vert} 2$Ë°®Á§∫ÊóãËΩ¨ËßíÂ∫¶, $r{vert}$Ë°®Á§∫ÊóãËΩ¨ÂêëÈáè
    • ÂõõÂÖÉÊï∞‰∏éÁ©∫Èó¥ÊóãËΩ¨
  • cv2
    • Rodrigues
      • cv2.Rodrigues(rotvec)[0]: ÊóãËΩ¨ÂêëÈáèÂà∞ÊóãËΩ¨Áü©Èòµ
      • cv2.Rodrigues(rotmatrix)[0]: ÊóãËΩ¨Áü©ÈòµÂà∞ÊóãËΩ¨ÂêëÈáè

Conversion

c r c t o r obj t obj scale status comment
9.3,153.1,106.7 -43.2,99.3,83.8 0 0 0,-1,0 ‚úî c r = inv(mat)zxy,xyz=[-,-,+], t = xyz[+,+,-]
9.3,153.1,106.7 0 0 43.2,-99.3,-83.8 0,-1,0 ‚úî c r = inv(mat)zxy,xyz=[-,-,+],o t = xyz[-,-,+]

From unity to pytorch3d

  • unity$(t=(x,y,z),r=(\theta_x,\theta_y,\theta_z))$
  • pytorch3d$(t=(-x,y,z)),r=(-\theta_x,\theta_y,\theta_z)$
  • code
    • equivalence transformation
    • euler to euler
     verts *= [-1,1,1]
 theta_x, theta_y, theta_z = angles
 rotation=R.from_euler("yxz", [theta_y, theta_x, theta_z], degrees=True).as_matrix()
 trans *= [-1,1,1]
    • unity.quat to scipy.euler
     # quat from unity [10,-120,70]
 quat = [0.459144592,0.731702268,-0.347525775,-0.364724457]
 euler = R.from_quat(quat).as_euler('zxy')
 euler *= [1,-1,1]
 rotation = R.from_euler('yxz', euler[[2,1,0]]).as_matrix()

Reference

  • Pytorch3D - Camera Coordinate Systems
  • Pytorch3D - Coordinate transformation conventions, with OpenGL
  • Github issue - The rendering results of pytorch3d and opencv are different
  • Medium - What are the coordinates?
  • ‰∏∫‰ªÄ‰πàÂõõÂÖÉÊï∞ÊØîÊ¨ßÊãâËßíÊõ¥Â•Ω
    • ËÆ°ÁÆóÊú∫Âä®Áîª Ôºö ‰∏áÂêëËäÇÊ≠ªÈîÅGimbal LockÁöÑÊú¨Ë¥® - Âç¢Â∞èÂÖ≠ÁöÑÊñáÁ´† - Áü•‰πé
    • Gimbal lock - WikiPedia
    • Euler Angle - github.io

entry.title: Normal Device Coordinate with Different System

link.title: Normal Device Coordinate with Different System

entry.content:
NDC [Normal Device Coordinate] Ê†áÂáÜÂåñËÆæÂ§áÂùêÊ†á

  • Clip coordinates - Wikipedia
  • assume the coordinate system in math
    • x: outside the screen
    • y: right side
    • z: up side
  • NDC coordinate system
platform coordinate system rotation cite
pytorch 3d right hand left hand, clockwise pytorch3d doc
unity left hand left hand, clockwise aclockworkberry
OpenGL right hand ¬† OpenGL doc
  • ÂùêÊ†áÁ≥ªÊâãÊÄß
    • Âè≥ÊâãÊè°‰ΩèzÔºå4Êåá‰ªéxÂà∞yÔºåÊãáÊåáÊñπÂêë‰∏∫Ê≠£ÔºåÂàô‰∏∫Âè≥ÊâãÂùêÊ†áÁ≥ª
    • Âèç‰πã‰∏∫Â∑¶ÊâãÂùêÊ†áÁ≥ª
    • Ê¨ßÊãâËßíÔºåÂú®ÂØπÂ∫îÁöÑÊâãÊÄßÂùêÊ†áÁ≥ª‰∏≠ÔºåÊè°‰ΩèÊóãËΩ¨ËΩ¥ÔºåËã•‰∏éÊãáÊåáÂêåÂêëÔºåÂàôËΩ¨Ëßí‰∏∫Ê≠£ÔºåÂê¶Âàô‰∏∫Ë¥ü
  • camera
    • pytorch
      • RTÂèÇÊï∞‰ΩøÁâ©‰ΩìÊóãËΩ¨ÔºåÁõ∏Êú∫‰∏çÂä®

      • CONVENTIONS We adopt a right-hand coordinate system, meaning that rotation about an axis with a positive angle results in a counter clockwise rotation.

      • ÊóãËΩ¨ÊñπÂêëÈ°∫Êó∂Èíà‰∏∫Ê≠£ÔºåÊãáÊåá‰∏∫ËΩ¥ÊñπÂêëÔºåÂõõÊåá‰∏∫ÊóãËΩ¨ÊñπÂêëÔºåleft hand
    • unity
      • RTÂèÇÊï∞‰ΩøÁõ∏Êú∫ÂèòÊç¢ÔºåÁâ©‰Ωì‰∏çÂä®
      • ÊóãËΩ¨ÊñπÂêëÈ°∫Êó∂Èíà‰∏∫Ê≠£ÔºåÊãáÊåá‰∏∫ËΩ¥ÊñπÂêëÔºåÂõõÊåá‰∏∫ÊóãËΩ¨ÊñπÂêëÔºåleft hand
  • 3dmax, unity, unreal
  • pytorch3d

entry.title: 3D Render Lib Python
entry.content:
Python 3D render engine

  • 3D Scene Renderer for Python [closed] - stackoverflow
    • First-rate, full game engines (have been used for commercial games)
      • Panda3d
